That depends on your need. Using=
 longs to represent everything in pennies fails when you are attempting to =
use multiple currencies. As an example from our product taken at today's ra=
te.

1 USD =3D 3.36820 PEN (Peru Nuevos Soles)

Thus a $10.56 transaction i=
s S/35,57 (rounds up according to our local contact). So now that I have ta=
ken 100 transactions throughout the day I have S/355,70 in my cash drawer, =
but someone seeing it from the USD side will think that there is $105.60 in=
 the drawer - which converts into S/355,68. Thus the drawer doesn't balance=
.
	Now add in the complexity that the purchaser in question wants to give y=
ou $5 and pay the rest in PEN (S/18,73). The customer loves this because th=
e more USD they get in the better off they are (stable currency and all of =
that). Thus at the end of the day they might have PEN, USD, and EUR in thei=
r drawer.
	Now all of this could be avoided if you accept 4 decimal digits =
for money - 1 away from your significant should cancel any rounding errors,=
 or you can get each transaction as an individual. However, if you only get=
 a lump long for the amount then it won't work.

I have found BigDecimal is=
 actually very accurate when you initially load values into them using Stri=
ngs [new BigDecimal("10.56")], so I have been using them.
